text:
Fundamentally, what I love
so much about the case method

is that we go into the
field to learn something

about how some of our research
may be playing out or really

extending our research
into a new direction.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
We bring it into the classroom.

And we have the
ability to test it out

with diverse groups of
people, to find out,

how do they respond to these
insights, what can I learn,

what question would I really
want to have answered,
and how do people feel about it?

And it's this iterative loop
between testing, evaluating,

gaining new knowledge, and
then going back in and doing it

all over again that
really excites me.

The case method allows me
to show, as opposed to tell,

others about a phenomena and,
therefore, learn with them

as they discover, and
I discover with them,

what are the key lessons we
can take from looking deeply
at a particular circumstance?

The best cases put students
in the role of detective.

A great case, together
with a great teaching plan,

will enable them to
unearth the root causes

and formulate courses
of action that

capture the best insights of
our research and go beyond that.

And the case method enables
students to walk away

making the knowledge, making
the insight, making the skills
their own.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
